body: @mahsaNajafzadeh can you try 2.12.1 as there was a similar bug recently fixed.

@ldcsaa thank you for posting the example data. My first goal is to understand what is happening, so if I mention something is a problem in the data, please don't take it personally :P I will take a look now and see
I agree with your assessment of trace 1. looking into the second
also I agree with the 2nd. My hypothesis is that children are not sorted by timestamp as we traverse the trace
so interestingly `traceToMustache` returns `modelview.spans` in the correct order. looking closer at what could cause this..
`trace.js/showSpans` is invoked with the later span first.. guessing it is somewhere before this, then
`page/traceViewer.js` gets the spans in the wrong order... looking between now
component_ui/trace.js has the spans in opposite order (forgive me for posting notes, it is really hard to figure out what the heck is going on)
ok taking a break maybe I can figure this out later

Related #2351 

> leaf spans should use remoteEndpoint service name rather than the localEndpoint. If the SERVER span exists, the server's localEndpoint should be used (same as now).

consider the merge an approval :)

thanks!
ok yesterday I must not have noticed that traceViewer.js gets the span in the wrong order which is the same as presentation

Ah - in that case I suspect it's not needed. That API is using annotated service, not actuator. From what I can tell from these docs, actuator requires content type header so the default path mapping probably works

https://docs.spring.io/spring-boot/docs/current/actuator-api/html/#loggers-single

dunno probably something must have failed else I wouldnt have written this.
the version of me that knew was force pushed

I have a private trace locally that still doesn't work. not merging until I figure out why

A few non-func points from me:

1. Pulsar provides truly async client, while Kafka is coming from the blocking world
2. Pulsar consumer API is simpler than Kafka's (where if you don't poll you might end up de-assigned from the partition (sic!))
3. Running Kafka behind NAT is problematic, while Pulsar can be used with a proxy
4. Pulsar SQL is a driver for Presto, not a brand new tech from scratch by a commercial owner of the tech
5. Backing up Pulsar clusters is much easier thanks to the tiered storage

@anuraaga I played with building from your branch of armeria, but I get a mysterious NPE in the exploratory commit

```
[ERROR] Failed to execute goal org.apache.maven.plugins:maven-invoker-plugin:3.2.0:install (integration-test) on project zipkin-server: Failed to install project dependencies: MavenProject: io.zipkin.java:zipkin-server:2.12.2-SNAPSHOT @ /Users/acole/oss/zipkin/zipkin-server/pom.xml: Failed to install project artifacts: null: Failed to install POM: null: NullPointerException -> [Help 1]
```
Is there any work going on for postgres persistence support ? Any way I can help ?
Is 2) a problem? I think in this case we care mostly about the publisher API (agent/middleware -> pulsar) which can also be batched/delayed locally (at risk of loss).

No2 is an advantage of Pulsar, not a problem :) Sorry for confusing :)

Also, Kafka's publisher can block on publish, even if async API is used, while afaik there is no such issue in Pulsar

No problem. I think Kafka did mitigate the blocking client a bit in the last releases (just for fairness/completeness of the argument)  https://cwiki.apache.org/confluence/display/KAFKA/KIP-266%3A+Fix+consumer+indefinite+blocking+behavior
Only in the consumer part, but there are still blocking calls in Kafka's async producer :(

work here needs champions to run it through. If you like, you can look at
the work-on-progress voltdb experiment as an example, though in the schema
likely completing normalization of the data is preferred (unclear on this
really)
https://github.com/adriancole/zipkin-voltdb

Anyway, you can create a repo based on this to start toying with it. Right
now, no one has worked on postgres
ok, i will discuss it on gitter.
https://github.com/openzipkin/zipkin/pull/2386 fixes this.. note this was one popular part of the last UI attempt https://github.com/openzipkin-attic/zipkin-ui
looks good. maybe in a test show with good and bad data? ex missing client receive or server send (one-way)
@yinjihuan  you can set lookback to 0 and try again.
This looks amazing! Thanks!

These are [netflix.json](https://github.com/openzipkin/zipkin/blob/master/zipkin-ui/testdata/netflix.json) and [ascend.json](https://github.com/openzipkin/zipkin/blob/master/zipkin-ui/testdata/ascend.json).

Maybe ascend.json is a bit strange.

It has following span data.

```
    ...,
    {
        ...,
        "id": "52b1ab4956917c39",
        "kind": "CLIENT",
        "timestamp": 1531282088533834,
        "duration": 14077,
        ...,
    },
    {
        "id": "52b1ab4956917c39",
        "kind": "SERVER",
        "name": "http:/parent/auth-service/v1/authentications/",
        "timestamp": 1531282088553000,
        "duration": 4157,
        "localEndpoint": {
            "serviceName": "auth-service",
            ...,
        },
        ...,
        "shared": true
    },
    ...
```

`Client` → `...33834` ~ `...47911`
`Server` → `...53000` ~ `...57157`

I think this is pretty confusing right now. Maybe if you have autocomplete tags enable it looks better but without them it just seems broken.

When I select tags it just gives me an empty textbox with no instruction on what to do. At least in the old ui we have the example query.

one other thing to test.. is to make a really really short client/server span.. like one that completes in less than a millisecond, whereas other spans have a different scale like more than a millisecond. This might show some rendering issues
there is a problem when a parent is a shared span.. the children don't sort correctly. I have narrowed this down but not yet fixed. Thanks @drolando for the test data.

OK, so the ordering is interfered with when the IP address changes in the middle of the trace. I think it is actually a recording bug, but anyway will think about it. @drolando I captured the essential part of your trace here, masking the original trace ID and IPs, but the span IDs should match your trace ```json [ { "traceId": "1", "parentId": "d3641a4ed9ad3148", "id": "e1590f0eb996eeb3", "name": "get /my/foot", "timestamp": 1549852763488172, "duration": 16640, "localEndpoint": { "serviceName": "my-service", "ipv4": "10.2.3.4" } }, { "traceId": "1", "parentId": "d3641a4ed9ad3148", "id": "b7325a5ae5c8bf74", "kind": "CLIENT", "name": "get", "timestamp": 1549852763158000, "duration": 13000, "localEndpoint": { "serviceName": "my-service", "ipv4": "169.2.3.4" } }, { "traceId": "1", "parentId": "f916a1763ed039b1", "id": "d3641a4ed9ad3148", "kind": "SERVER", "name": "get /me", "timestamp": 1549852763151857, "duration": 525280, "localEndpoint": { "serviceName": "my-service", "ipv4": "10.2.3.4" }, "shared": true } ] ```
@drolando this is a different issue, a topological problem. I fix it separately

any suggestions? maybe use OSX preview to annotate a screenshot with
something more intuitive?

This is a work in progress to investigate what is actually interfering with the sort order. I didn't actually change the javascript code for this test to pass, which means I got something wrong.

@xeraa do you know which version rollover index was added? I agree the core issue here is size.

I have a work testing now, which will use single-character wildcard on search `_` and explicit characters on insert. So, for <7 index-type delimiter `:` and >=7 `-`. It occurred to me that since we use the hyphen delimiter elsewhere, if this becomes banned by ES in the future it will break everything else. Instead of waiting for a special character to be cleared and not working with ES7 at all, better to assume they won't break hyphen until that's not the case.
hmm maybe "_" isn't allowed in the POST urls...
PS we can't really test all of this independently as there is more than just the one issue here before Elasticsearch 7 works

@adriancole that would be awesome! didn't know this effort before, but it would be great if @afalko @rmichela could check if https://github.com/jeqo/zipkin-storage-kafka covers their use-cases before.

Leading `_` are not allowed for index names. Unfortunately we don't have whitelisted characters in our docs ATM, but both `-` and `_` are very widely used, so I have high hopes that those will stay around 😅

@adriancole 6.6 (the current version): https://www.elastic.co/guide/en/elasticsearch/reference/6.6/index-lifecycle-management.html

You can fully managed it through the Elasticsearch API, but Kibana also provides a UI for it. And as I said: Not open source but free to use (Basic license).

@adriancole 
- yes,if `okhttp3.Dns` use `InetSocketAddress`,the problem will be solved.
- the problem seems to be not very urgent,if really need,we can implement a simple `round robin` using the `InetSocketAddress` inside（：D）.
- I don't know why choose` okhttp3` which's more suitable for mobile development?

- I don't know why choose okhttp3 which's more suitable for mobile
   development?

We chose okhttp because it is a clean, well designed library, that keeps
api portability in mind. It is not exclusively targeted to mobile dev even
if they care about android.

to set expectations.. lens has been in progress for months. the only reason
we are doing this at all is to remove FUD about pulling the trigger and
actually releasing lens as default.

Meanwhile, people are still looking at zipkin as if lens doesnt exist.

The primary motive of this wasnt to create a flip flop for an extended
beta, but rather the minimum infra to reduce the burden of maintaining 2
uis simultaneously.. and dispelling myth that lens doesnt exist.

if we add an icon on lens to go back, people may have impression that we
will be keeping the old ui which we certainly wont. it will be deleted
ideally within a month

make sense?
